{{disambig-two|the Gondorian corsair|for the Quenya [[epessë]] of Angrod|[[Angamaitë (epessë)]]}} {{infobox character | people=[[Gondorians|Gondorian]] | name=Angamaitë | image=Liz Danforth - Angamaitë.jpg | caption="Angamaitë" by [[Liz Danforth]] | pronun=[[Quenya|Q]], {{IPA|[ˌaŋɡaˈma͡ɪtɛ]}} | othernames= | titles= | position= | location=[[Umbar]] | affiliation=[[Corsairs of Umbar]] | language= | birth= | birthlocation= | rule= | death= | deathlocation= | age= | notablefor= | house=[[House of Anárion]] | parentage=''unknown''; great-grandson of [[Castamir]] | siblings= | spouse= | children= | gender=Male | height= | hair= | eyes= | clothing= | weapons= | steed= }} '''Angamaitë''' was one of the great-grandsons of [[Castamir]] the Usurper.{{App|Gondor}}, entry for king Telemnar == History == He and [[Sangahyando]], another great-grandson of Castamir, were leaders of the [[Corsairs of Umbar]].{{PM|Elendil}}, manuscript C, The Heirs of Elendil, The Southern Line of Gondor: the Anarioni, 25. Minardil, p. 199 The name Angamaitë was possibly not his birth name, but a personal warrior name (or nickname). There was no need to assert his royal descent with this name, because his royal descent was clear.{{L|347}} Angamaitë and Sangayando learned through spies that [[Minardil]], the [[King of Gondor]], was in the [[Gondor]]ian port of [[Pelargir]] and that he suspected no peril since his father had crushed Harad and Umbar. In {{TA|1634}}{{App|TA}}, entry for the year 1634{{PM|Third}}, manuscript T4, entry for the year 1634 the Corsairs of Umbar, led by Angamaitë and Sangayando, made a raid up the river [[Anduin]], killed king Minardil in Pelargir, ravaged Pelargir and the coasts and escaped with great booty. == Etymology == {{Seealso|Angamaitë (epessë)}} ''Angamaitë'' is a [[Quenya]] name meaning "Iron-handed", from ''[[anga]]'' ("iron") and ''[[maitë]]'' ("handed").{{PE|17}}, p. 116 entry Q ''angamaite'' and p. 162 entry '''MAG''' == Genealogy == {{familytree/start}} {{familytree | | | CAL | | |CAL=[[Calimehtar (son of Calmacil)|Calimehtar]]
''unknown''}} {{familytree | | | |:| | | |}} {{familytree | | | CAS | | |CAS=[[Castamir]]
''{{TA|1259|n}} - {{TA|1447|n}}''†}} {{familytree | | | |!| | | |}} {{familytree | | | SON | | |SON=''sons''
''unknown''†}} {{familytree | |F|~|A|~|7| |}} {{familytree | |:| | | |:| |}} {{familytree | ANG | | SAN |ANG='''ANGAMAITË'''
''fl. {{TA|1634|n}}''|SAN=[[Sangahyando]]
''fl. {{TA|1634|n}}''}} {{familytree/end}} == Other versions of the legendarium == In the manuscripts for what would later become appendix A and appendix B and in appendix A in the first edition of ''[[The Lord of the Rings]]'' his name was ''Angomaitë''. His name was changed to ''Angamaitë'' in the second edition of The Lord of the Rings.{{PM|Elendil}}, Commentary relating to the entry for king Minardil in manuscript B, p. 215 {{references}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Angamaite}} [[Category:Dúnedain]] [[Category:House of Anárion]] [[Category:Mariners]] [[Category:Quenya names]] [[Category:Third Age characters]] [[de:Angamaite]] [[fr:encyclo:personnages:hommes:3a:dunedain:angamaite]] [[fi:Angamaitë (ihminen)]]
